importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the LEAP trial findings were published and new medical guidelines were issued, leading to a shift in pediatric allergy practices.
When the recommendations for early peanut introduction were expanded, resulting in a more significant drop in peanut allergy rates among children.
The updated national guidance for introducing major food allergens between four and six months of age, without prior screening.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The decade-long period during which early peanut introduction policies have led to measurable declines in pediatric food allergies.

keyTakeAways: The rate of peanut allergies in children aged 0 to 3 declined by over 27% after 2015 and by over 40% after 2017 due to early allergen introduction guidelines.
About 40,000 children avoided peanut allergies since 2015, according to the research, with about 60,000 children overall avoiding food allergies (corrected to 40,000 for peanut allergies).
Early introduction of peanut products in infancy reduces future risk of food allergies by more than 80%, as shown in the LEAP trial.
The updated 2021 guidelines recommend introducing peanuts and other major allergens between 4 and 6 months of age, without prior screening or testing.
Despite initial hesitancy, adoption of early allergen introduction practices has increased, with new research showing measurable public health impact.
Medical professionals and parents are now advised to introduce small amounts of peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters in a safe and gradual way.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He led the analysis of health records that demonstrated a decline in peanut allergies after the implementation of early introduction guidelines.

namedEntities.name: Gideon Lack

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His 2015 LEAP study first demonstrated that early peanut exposure significantly reduces the risk of developing peanut allergies.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after the LEAP trial demonstrated that early introduction of peanuts to infants reduces the risk of developing peanut allergies by over 80%, new research shows a significant decline in allergy rates in the U.S. The rate of peanut allergies in children aged 0 to 3 dropped by over 27% after 2015 and by over 40% after 2017 due to updated medical guidelines. Dr. David Hill and colleagues analyzed electronic health records from pediatric practices and found that around 40,000 children avoided peanut allergies since 2015. Despite initial resistance and slow adoption among healthcare providers—only 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists followed the 2017 guidance—the practice is now being widely implemented and appears to be having measurable public health benefits. Experts like Dr. David Hill and FARE advocate for introducing allergenic foods like peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, and soy-based products between four and six months of age in small, safe amounts. This shift reflects a broader movement toward evidence-based infant nutrition to reduce the incidence of life-threatening food allergies.
title: New Research Shows Early Introduction of Peanuts in Infants Is Reducing Allergy Rates in the U.S.
